articles.headline: The Trade War’s Latest Casualties: China’s Coddled Cats and Dogs
articles.snippet: Some Chinese pet owners don’t trust local food and will even taste it themselves before serving it. For them, the fight means fewer and pricier choices.
articles.abstract: Some Chinese pet owners don’t trust local food and will even taste it themselves before serving it. For them, the fight means fewer and pricier choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Olivia Ren never expected a trade war between the United States and China to affect Dada.
articles.byline: By Ailin Tang and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: On Jamal Khashoggi Killing, Trump Administration Sends Mixed Signals
articles.snippet: The C.I.A. director is helping the Turkish government with its inquiry into the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, and the Treasury secretary held a wide-ranging meeting with the Saudi crown prince.
articles.abstract: The C.I.A. director is helping the Turkish government with its inquiry into the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, and the Treasury secretary held a wide-ranging meeting with the Saudi crown prince.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration, confronted with further evidence of a cover-up in the killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi, veered on Monday between defending the value of its alliance with Saudi Arabia and pressing the Saudi government for answers.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Trump and G.O.P. Candidates Escalate Race and Fear as Election Ploys
articles.snippet: The president’s unsubstantiated charge that “unknown Middle Easterners” were part of the migrant caravan was an escalation of his efforts to stoke fears ahead of the Nov. 6 vote.
articles.abstract: The president’s unsubstantiated charge that “unknown Middle Easterners” were part of the migrant caravan was an escalation of his efforts to stoke fears ahead of the Nov. 6 vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump on Monday sharply intensified a Republican campaign to frame the midterm elections as a battle over immigration and race, issuing a dark and factually baseless warning that “unknown Middle Easterners” were marching toward the American border with Mexico.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: What Could Hold Back a Democratic Wave? Economy, Confidence, Independence
articles.snippet: In battleground districts across the nation, a “life is good” ethos may make swing voters harder to persuade than some Democrats anticipate.
articles.abstract: In battleground districts across the nation, a “life is good” ethos may make swing voters harder to persuade than some Democrats anticipate.
articles.lead_paragraph: YARDLEY, Pa. — Sitting at her pumpkin-decorated dining room table, Kristen Donnelly ticked off her top political concerns: pay equity for women, gun control and anti-immigrant sentiment. (Her husband of five years has a green card.)
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Paul Volcker, at 91, Sees ‘a Hell of a Mess in Every Direction’
articles.snippet: In an interview, the former Fed chairman had a feisty take on the state of politics and government.
articles.abstract: In an interview, the former Fed chairman had a feisty take on the state of politics and government.
articles.lead_paragraph: This interview was published in 2018. Paul Volcker died on Sunday. Read our obituary here.

articles.headline: E.U. Rejects Italy’s Budget, and Populists Dig In
articles.snippet: The European Commission told Rome that it would have to rewrite its draft 2019 budget and reduce its deficit, or face heavy fines early next year.
articles.abstract: The European Commission told Rome that it would have to rewrite its draft 2019 budget and reduce its deficit, or face heavy fines early next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — In what is becoming a dangerous game of chicken for the global economy, Italy’s populist government refused to budge on Tuesday after the European Union for the first time sent back a member state’s proposed budget because it violated the bloc’s fiscal laws and posed unacceptable risks.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Steven Erlanger
